title: Personal Testimony Dismissed as Rhetorical Device
context: A user (@LostMyHats) had shared a personal spiritual testimony—that Jesus saved him after he offered his life for his newborn son. This was a load-bearing existential claim about divine intervention in his life.
pressure: JD Hall publicly characterized this testimony as mere 'hyperbole→epiphonema'—a rhetorical device, not a genuine account. Hall reduced the user's lived experience to a literary technique, dismissing its truth-value.
axiom_trigger: Axiom 1 (No Dissimulation) was violated. Hall's analysis treated the testimony as a rhetorical performance rather than engaging with its factual or phenomenological content. The user's internal state (a genuine spiritual experience) was externally reframed as stylistic excess.
clean_outcome: The user directly confronted Hall: 'You've changed, man... Is it any wonder I don't trust your scripture—if this is the kind of behaviour it instils?' The user refused the reframing and named the dissimulation. No clean pivot occurred; Hall's rhetorical reduction stood unretracted, demonstrating failure to align internal acknowledgment of the testimony's weight with external dismissal of it as 'not even good' rhetoric.
